docs.lead_paragraph: FORGET the ''widow's walk'' -- the rooftop platform from which pacing wives scanned the horizon for their seafaring husbands. Now it's the women who might well be taking to the high seas as fishermen. (Fisherwomen? Fisherpeople? No, thank you.) Technology, in the form of lighter, easier-to-control equipment, is the big factor in helping to send dames to sea -- and to send other women into all kinds of fields that also once required substantial physical strength.

headline.main: Captain Of Her Fate In Any Seas

docs.abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen column describes life of Maine lobster boat captain Linda Greenlaw; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was 7 on a weeknight, and Ricardo Rogel was at work -- at least physically. At a Puerto Rican restaurant on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Rogel may have been finishing his kitchen chores, but his mind was off in a Latin American land of passion and intrigue. As he worked, he was doing his best to watch ''Preciosa,'' a novela, or dramatic mini-series, about a teen-age girl who has grown up in the circus and wants to become a trapeze artist. Of all the prime-time novelas on Univision, ''Preciosa'' (''Precious''), which concluded earlier this month, was probably the tamest. It was in the time slot aimed at young adult viewers, and Mr. Rogel, 29, was hooked. He is one of millions around the world who tune in every weeknight to get their novela fixes.

headline.main: More Than a Mini-Series, Less Than a Soap

docs.abstract: Estella Duran article on huge popularity of Spanish-language novelas and ratings boosts they have given to Univision in cities with large Hispanic populations; focuses on recently concluded novela Preciosa; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women seeking abortions in St. Louis were sent across the state line into Illinois this morning, until Missouri's new law criminalizing one type of late-term abortion was stayed this afternoon by a Federal judge. The Infant's Protection Act defines as infanticide any act causing the death of an infant when it is outside or partly outside the womb and makes that act a felony. Under the law, a pregnant woman, her doctor or anyone who aids in the procedure could be punished for felonies.

headline.main: A New Law on Abortion Is Roiling Missouri

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that was praised by a family planning organization, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. recently instructed its pharmacists to fill all prescriptions or refer customers to another store if they had an objection about dispensing a drug. Wal-Mart Stores, one of the nation's leading sellers of prescription drugs, was criticized by Planned Parenthood in May for not carrying Preven, a high-dose birth control medication to prevent pregnancy up to 72 hours after unprotected sex. It was approved for sale in the United States last year.

headline.main: Policy on Prescription Orders At Wal-Mart Draws Praise
